awd_titl_txt: LTREB: Evolutionary and demographic responses to climate in natural populations
awd_abstract_narration:
The purpose of this study is to understand how a rapidly changing environment influences natural selection and population size. Many species of plants and animals can be threatened by rapid environmental change, such as an increase in frequency or severity of drought. This research will test the conditions required for a population to avoid collapse due to climate change through a process of adapting to the new environmental conditions. It will add to the longest-running data set on how selection in plants changes in response to changes in annual snowpack and pollinator availability, and to model for the first time how adaptation to these conditions allows populations to recover. It will determine how selective pressures change in response to water availability, how genetic variation in leaf and flower traits interact with climate change to affect birth and death rates, and how changes in pollination patterns and rates interact with the physical environment to influence evolutionary change. Responses of population size to climate change will be projected over the next century and provide a case study of how other species might respond. The project will include the training of diverse undergraduate and graduate students and a postdoctoral associate. Field science tours at the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory will be led for outreach to the general public and to K-12 teachers. In addition, a citizen science project will allow the public to contribute to the building of maps of pollinator abundance across the western US.

This project will continue a 10-year field experiment with common gardens near the Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory to measure natural selection on, and the extent of genetic variance in, traits of Ipomopsis aggregata subspp. aggregata and Ipomopsis tenuituba (Polemoniaceae). In combination with unique data on how absolute fitness is altered by snowmelt date, models for evolutionary rescue will be fully parameterized in nature. The relationship between selection of functional vegetative traits and water availability will be determined with two approaches: observational data on selection over two decades and a new experimental manipulation of snowmelt date and summer precipitation. The project will examine the dependence of evolutionary and demographic responses on genetic variance in traits, as measured from a full-sib breeding design. The extent of adaptive phenotypic plasticity in response to annual snowmelt date will also be incorporated into projections of population size. Although prior studies of plant adaptation to climate have emphasized vegetative traits, floral traits (shape, color, rewards, volatiles) will be modeled as well, as selection on them depends on water availability and pollinator abundance.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF LTREB supported long-term study of how climate change influences natural selection, evolution and demography of populations, using two closely related species of subalpine Ipomopsis plants as a model. One way that populations can persist in the face of climate change is through evolutionary rescue by adaptation to the new environmental conditions. This award (2017-2022) built upon measurements of natural selection that began in 2001 to test hypotheses about the conditions under which evolutionary rescue is possible.

A first step was documenting the impacts of climate change on population growth in the absence of evolution. This project produced the first example leveraging long-term data to show that climate change will cause a plant population to decline due to low seed production. Based on the historical trend in snowmelt date, some populations are already below replacement, and others are expected to fall below replacement in the next one to four decades. By incorporating additional long-term data, we showed that this impact is due primarily to a shift towards earlier snowmelt in the spring, which matters more to population growth in this plant than do the species interactions of pollination and seed predation.

We then began tests of five hypotheses about evolutionary rescue, using a combination of two approaches: experimental manipulations of snowmelt timing and summer precipitation (both of which alter annual water availability) and comparisons of natural selection across years that differ naturally in water availability. The first hypothesis states that natural selection for vegetative traits depends on annual water availability and was supported for the traits of stomatal conductance (loss of water through leaf pores) and water-use efficiency during photosynthesis, but not for other leaf traits measured.  

The second hypothesis was that evolutionary and demographic responses will be higher when traits have higher genetic variance. Measurements of genetic variability in common field gardens indicated stronger genetic potential for evolutionary responses in floral morphology compared with floral scent compounds and vegetative traits. Floral traits typically measured (flower shape, color, and rewards) exhibited higher heritabilities than either floral scent (measured here for the first time in field settings) or vegetative traits.  Genetic correlations were higher between floral traits than between one floral trait and one vegetative trait, indicating that the two sets of traits could evolve largely independently.

Third, we hypothesized that adaptive phenotypic plasticity will modify the demographic effects of evolution. Earlier snowmelt caused several plastic changes, including reduced photosynthesis, reduced stomatal conductance, increased density of leaf hairs and increased water-use efficiency. The increased water-use efficiency in turn increased fitness under dry conditions, thus showing adaptive phenotypic plasticity. Several aspects of floral morphology also responded directly to the date of snowmelt timing and summer precipitation.

Our fourth hypothesis was that evolutionary responses will be modified by changes in natural selection on multiple reproductive traits. We found evidence for strong selection on some reproductive traits that also show heritability and the potential to evolve. Natural selection on floral scent and morphology was stronger during pollination than during seed predation. We demonstrated stabilizing selection on the major scent compound, the first time that non-linear selection on floral scent had been investigated in nature. Effects of one trait on pollination often depended on values of other traits. Our estimates of pollinator selection can accurately predict evolutionary change. Observed changes in flower shape over 25 years are highly consistent with values predicted from selection and heritability. We look forward to examining how those evolutionary changes in turn can affect the persistence of the populations. Tests are ongoing for our final hypothesis that the potential for evolutionary rescue depends on the form of environmental change.

Our findings have been broadly disseminated in 9 scientific journal articles. We also maintain an open science framework website (https://osf.io/) that helps to disseminate results and data sets (?Long-term data on plant traits and fitness of Ipomopsis?). Results have been presented in 11 talks at universities, field stations (Rocky Mountain Biological Laboratory in Colorado), and scientific meetings both within the US and internationally.

Broader impacts have included training 11 undergraduates, 5 graduate students, 2 postdocs, and 2 faculty members. Population models and methods of sampling plant volatiles developed for this project were incorporated into courses at the University of California and a graduate course at the University of Puerto Rico. The project has also included numerous tours for the public at the RMBL demonstrating topics in pollination, chemical ecology, and insect sensory perception.
